name: Jet
ram: 48 KB + 16 KB masked by the ROM
colors: 8 with two tones each (normal and bright)
ports: RF video out, RGB out, expansion port (not connected), tape-recorder (In, Out, Rem), external loudspeaker
power: Built-in power supply, 220 Vca + 10%, - 15%, 50 Hz +/- 1 Hz, Max power: 15 W
description:
We have few information about this computer.
The Jet was a Romanian Spectrum clone computer built in a telephone case! You can see the handset housing and the numeric keyboard replaced with black plastic masks.
The keyboard was made of printed pieces of paper inserted in transparent key-caps.
This system has been deeply modified by the user(s).

Zeno Mateescu, who owned a JET, reports:

The whole computer was more a HC-85 clone, designed more specificaly for computer games. That's where the name came from: JET-EM Aparat pentru jocuri pe ecran TV - machine for games on TV screen - if I remember well. It is indeed a Sinclair ZX Spectrum compatible computer. It didn't had any joystick connector (kempston or any other joystick) so I had to modify it to use a joystick. Another interesting thing about JET was that you
couldn't hear the program that was loading from the tape. On HC85, for example, you could hear that, let's call it noise, when loading the program.

Output signals:
- pal video signal: PAL: 1 Vvv / 75 ohm;
- radio signal: 1 mVeff / 75 ohm;
- the signal for the cassete recorder: 05 Vvv / 1 Kohm
Input signal from the cassete recorder: min 50 mVeff
Internal beeper: min. 55 dB SPL


_________

Contributors: Costel Dumitru

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JET (YELLOW MODEL)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Need a phone? You got a computer!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Zeno Mateescu for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Zeno Mateescu for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard was of poor quality. Each key was made of a colour printed piece of paper inserted in a key-cap.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Only one of the two system boards is pictured here.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Mains supply fuse<br> <b>(2)</b> Power transformer<br> <b>(3)</b> Voltage regulation circuit<br> <b>(4)</b> TV-RF modulator<br> <b>(5)</b> Reset switch<br> <b>(6)</b> Joystick connector<br> <b>(7)</b> RGB connector<br> <b>(8)</b> Basic interpreter and O.S. ROM chips (2 KB each)<br> <b>(9)</b> MME 880D processor. Zilog Z80 Russian clone<br> <b>(10)</b> Keyboard cable </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The second board featuring 8 KB of ROM is connected above the first one. It is difficult to know the use of this board as there is no inscription on top of the main chip.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>from left to right:  <br><br> - home-made joystick connector (direct connections to the keyboard cursor keys: 5,6,7,8 and 0)<br> - RF video output connector to TV<br> - External monitor connection?<br> - Tape recorder -> output for program saving <br> - Tape recorder -> input for program loading<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Zeno Mateescu for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With a cool teacher, computers is a child game" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Micro price, Mega features"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the traditional and strongly sterotyped promotional picture found on almost all 70s system boxes & leaflets... The whole family is there (parents and two children, a girl and a boy). They are drinking orange juice. Only males are playing, but girls are soooo happy to be allowed to watch the game...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>I bellissimi...<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Teleplay advert for the Teleng Colourstars<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.geocities.com/doubledragon0uk//Home.html" target="_blank">Double  Dragon Retro Mess</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 XMAS CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Soichiro Oga / <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Old PC leaflets museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Epson QX-10 advert appeared in January 1983. It took eight pages and explained the advantages of the Valdoc system, the benefits of the CP/M operating system compatibility, and the advanced hardware concepts.   <br><br> In conclusion, it said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The most important component is you</b><br> You don't buy a computer for how "smart" it is. You buy one for how smart it makes you.<br> The Epson QX-10 was conceived, designed, engineered and built with just one thought in mind: to vastly expand your ability to see, to think, to create with a system that acts as a natural extension of the human mind.<br> The QX-10 is not a computer designed to play games, although it plays games as well as any and better than most.<br> It's a computer for people who think.<br> And who want to think better.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DMS-15</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983 advert.<br><br> The DMS-15 is a DMS-3/F with a built-in 15 MB hard disk.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SHOW BAG</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Neurons' jogging"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our word processing system changed Isaac Asimov's mind about writing...<br> <b>"I may never use a typewriter again!"</b> Isaac likes the time he saves using SuperSCRIPSIT, our newest word processing program...<font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Basis 108. Microcomputin'g "Best Of Both Worlds"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Sinclair Phenomenon"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">... One of the results is our new identity and our new product: the Intersystems DPS-1. An IEEE S-100 compatible mainframe with features that live up to its look. <i>Dependable</i> operation to 4 Mhz. Twenty-card capacity, a modular power supply. And something no one else has: built-in break points to give you a faster, more powerful tool for testing software as well as hardware...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to <a href="http://blogs.linux.ie/fuzzbucket/archives/p/7/more/1/c/1/Vintage-Sinclair-QL-catalogue" target="_blank">fuzzbucket</a> for this complete QL catalogue.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
